subject: RE: [junit] Re: How to test private methods in a class.
msgSnippet: ... A public method is the core responsibility of a class. If we extract a private method, that private method basically provides a service to the public
messageBody:
junit@yahoogroups.com wrote:
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Ilja Preuss" <preuss@d...> wrote:
>>> (In fact, it's the fact that private methods tend to hide
>>> duplication that makes me want to avoid them).
>>
>> Somehow this resonates with my feelings, though I couldn't have put
>> it that way. Thanks for that!
>>
>
> How so? My experience is that private methods are frequently
> introduced specifically to remove duplication.

A public method is the core responsibility of a class. If we extract a
private method, that private method basically provides a service to the
public method.

It's true that we can remove duplication in a class by extracting private
methods. Often, though, if we introduce the right abstraction, we find that
the service provided can suddenly be used by other classes, too.

Does that sound reasonable?

Cheers, Ilja
